changes to the square root of the Lorentzian function close to the Sm-A–Hex-B phase transition [
while far away fromthe transition temperature it is well described by the simple Lorentzian function
(Equation (15)). The same interaction also slightly shifts the position of the scattering peaks along

Some conclusions about the evolution of the BO order at the Sm-A–Hex-B phase transition may
be drawn from considerations of the symmetry properties of these phases. The in-plane sixfold BO
order in the Hex-B phase can be described in real space by the fundamental BO order ﬁeld
direct determination of the molecular orientations in LCs is not possible, in an experiment it is more
common to use a set of the BOorder parameters

], which is characterized by a second-order phase transition in 3D(see the phase
). The transition of Sm-Ainto the hexagonal crystal phase Cr-B is always ﬁrst-order
in 3D due to the long-range positional order and the presence of a cubic term in the free-energy
expansion in powers of the Fourier coe
]. The same cubic term is present
for a Hex-B–Cr-B transition in 3D and gives rise to the ﬁrst-order transition. The two lines of the
ﬁrst-order transitions intersect on the phase diagramat slightly di
erent slopes, which also shifts the
Sm-A–Hex-B phase transition to the ﬁrst order [
]. This leads to the appearance of a tricritical point
on the Sm-A–Hex-B phase transition line in the vicinity of the Sm-A–Hex-B–Cr-B triple point (Figure
At the tricritical point the Sm-A–Hex-B phase transition changes its order fromﬁrst to second in the
vicinity of the Sm-A–Hex-B–Cr-B triple point (Figure
). As a result, in many LC compounds the
Sm-A–Hex-B phase transition occurs in the vicinity of the tricritical point.
phase transition [17,62], while far away from the transition temperature it is well described by the
simple Lorentzian function (Equation (15)). The same interaction also slightly shifts the position of
over the value proportional to the mean squared modulus of the
Some conclusions about the evolution of the BO order at the Sm-A–Hex-B phase transition may
be drawn from considerations of the symmetry properties of these phases. The in-plane sixfold BO
order in the Hex-B phase can be described in real space by the fundamental BO order field
the direct determination of the molecular orientations in LCs is not possible, in an experiment it is
more common to use a set of the BO order parameters
defined in reciprocal space according to
allows to describe the Sm-A–Hex-B phase transition within
the XY universality class [1], which is characterized by a second-order phase transition in 3D (see
the phase diagram in Figure 6). The transition of Sm-A into the hexagonal crystal phase Cr-B is
always first-order in 3D due to the long-range positional order and the presence of a cubic term in
the free-energy expansion in powers of the Fourier coefficients of the density [65]. The same cubic
term is present for a Hex-B–Cr-B transition in 3D and gives rise to the first-order transition. The two
lines of the first-order transitions intersect on the phase diagram at slightly different slopes, which
also shifts the Sm-A–Hex-B phase transition to the first order [17,40]. This leads to the appearance
of a tricritical point on the Sm-A–Hex-B phase transition line in the vicinity of the Sm-A–Hex-B–
Cr-B triple point (Figure 6). At the tricritical point the Sm-A–Hex-B phase transition changes its
order from first to second in the vicinity of the Sm-A–Hex-B–Cr-B triple point (Figure 6). As a
result, in many LC compounds the Sm-A–Hex-B phase transition occurs in the vicinity of the
Generic phase diagram of the LC in the vicinity of the Hex-B–Sm-A–Cr-B triple point for a
3D case according to [40]. Solid and dashed lines correspond to the first- and second-order phase
transitions, respectively (adopted from Zaluzhnyy et al. [17]––Published by The Royal Society of
Assuming that the Sm-A–Hex-B phase transition lies in a crossover region between the mean
field (tricritial behavior) and the 3D XY universality class, Aharony et al. [39,40] have shown that
satisfy the scaling relation, called the multicritical scaling

]. Solid and dashed lines correspond to the ﬁrst- and second-order phase
transitions, respectively (adopted from Zaluzhnyy et al. [

ﬁeld (tricritial behavior) and the 3D XY universality class, Aharony et al. [
satisfy the scaling relation, called the multicritical scaling theory
